title: Jeff Brazier wants it to be 'impossible' for teen sons to forget Jade Goody
text:
Jeff has two sons with Jade, who are now learning their way in the world (Picture: Instagram/jeffbrazier; Getty)

Jeff Brazier has opened up on the next stage of raising his growing sons with Jade Goody on his own, 10 years after the passing of the reality star and personality.

And, frankly, it sounds like while it’s been no walk in the park for him, he’s acing this parenting business.

Over a decade ago reality star and personality Jade died following a cervical cancer diagnosis, leaving two young sons, Bobby, 16, and Freddie, 15, with her former partner Jeff.

Bobby and Freddie were aged just six and five respectively when Jade passed away in March 2009, with Jeff having been separated from the Big Brother star by that time.

Recently Jeff revealed his two boys wouldn’t be watching the documentary made about Jade around the anniversary of her death, Channel 4’s Jade Goody: The Reality Star Who Changed Britain.

Jeff is close with his sons, here with Bobby, 16 (Picture: Channel 4)

Touching on some difficult times in their mum’s life, Jeff wondered whether it was appropriate for their sons to see. Speaking about it now to Metro.co.uk, he insisted it was their choice not to watch it, but he feels if they did he’d ‘still be picking up the pieces’.

‘It’s my job to pre-empt the bad stuff; re-experiencing watching your mum die, it’s going to be a new experience as teens. To experience with a greater level of understanding and comprehension,’ Jeff, 40, told us.

‘I’m not trying to make them forget, that is the complete opposite. I’m all up for maintaining the memory and keeping the love and they have a great sense of who mum was.

Jade Goody passed away 10 years ago from cervical cancer (Picture: Getty Images)

‘That documentary was not the right way to learn about their mum. There is some really adult, complicated things in it.

‘I got the godparents together to make sure there are more voices than my own. Those pre-emptive chats are vital; I’d probably still be picking up the pieces now. It’s there whenever they want to watch them – I won’t be able to stop them. But I want them to do it when they feel ready.’

When it comes to speaking about Jade and keeping her legacy alive, Jeff insisted it’s going to be ‘impossible’ for his sons to forget every memory they have of her, as he continues to teach them about the woman she was.

Jeff with his sons and partner Kate (Picture: Instagram/jeffbrazier)

‘I don’t feel a responsibility to [speak about her] publicly, but there absolutely is a responsibility for me to do that privately,’ he said. ‘Every time I take them to the grave, every time we talk about her, every time they see their godparents, you’re being respectful to her and I guess doing what I would hope she would have done for me if the roles were reversed.

Advertisement

‘It’s impossible for them to forget and not have those memories, she was far too important.’

As life continues to go along for Jeff and his family, he recently revealed his eldest Bobby has just gained an apprenticeship and is on the job learning after some stellar GCSE results.

Gaining a level of ‘freedom’ back in his life as his sons grow up and become young men, capable of looking after themselves, Jeff is excited about the next chapter.

The TV presenter has been supporting McDonald’s Ronald McDonald House Charities UK on its latest campaign. Showing the benefits of the charity’s new fundraising methods, introducing a ‘rounding-up’ system at the tills when you order, Jeff visited families at Evelina House and spoke to those who benefit most.

‘I’ve gone into McDonald’s for 30 odd years and I’ve never questioned what those collection boxes are on the counter. Those donations go towards helping families stay near their sick children while they’re in hospital by providing the free home away from home accommodation,’ he explained.

Advertisement

‘When you consider a cashless society, charities have been affected. If it wasn’t for that accommodation near the hospital, how on Earth would [parents] juggle work and other kids and everything life entails while trying to be that parent by their children. For some it would be absolutely impossible.’

Going through what he went through during Jade’s treatment, in and out of hospital with his young sons, does he find he’s in a better position to empathise with the struggles of families in RMH?

Jeff uses his platform on good causes (Picture: BACKGRID UK)

‘I can always show a lot of empathy, life experiences, negative ones will always be negative and moving forward it at least enables you to be a person that can show the right attitude towards others,’ Jeff said.

‘I think that’s part of being human. I would not want to be a version of myself that didn’t care about other people’s journeys, that would feel quite numb. I am grateful that I’m able to feel people.’

Finding more time to get back into football presenting on the weekends, now his boys are finding their way in the word, Jeff admits he feels proud of loosening the reins on his boys.

Advertisement

‘For the past 11 years it’s been all on me, the point I’ve got [Bobby] from school stage to work stage feels important and it’s freed something up for me. I feel less pressure, because he’s out there and doing things for himself,’ Jeff enthused, revealing he was getting back into football presenting.

‘I like the idea of him now taking the reins and being on his way’

Jeff is supporting McDonald’s raising money for the Ronald McDonald House Charities UK. Customers are now able to donate to the charity at kiosks in McDonald’s restaurants.
